abstractText: Two new glucosidated indole-containing quinazoline alkaloids designated fumigatosides G (1) and H (2) were isolated from mangrove-derived fungus Aspergillus fumigatus SAl12, together with the known analogues fumigatoside B (3) and fumiquinazoline J (4). The planar structures of the new compounds were elucidated by HR-MS and NMR spectroscopic data analyses. The absolute configurations were determined by comparison of electronic circular dichroic (ECD) spectra with that of the known compound fumigatoside B and with the calculated ECD spectrum. All these indole-quinazoline compounds were tested for anti-bacterial and cytotoxic activities.

references.title: Grincamycins I–K, cytotoxic angucycline glycosides derived from marine-derived actinomycete Streptomyces lusitanus SCSIO LR32

sections.text:
S1
Two new glucosidated indole-containing quinazoline alkaloids designated fumigatosides G (1) and H (2) were isolated from mangrove-derived fungus Aspergillus fumigatus SAl12, together with the known analogues fumigatoside B (3) and fumiquinazoline J (4). The planar structures of the new compounds were elucidated by HR-MS and NMR spectroscopic data analyses. The absolute configurations were determined by comparison of electronic circular dichroic (ECD) spectra with that of the known compound fumigatoside B and with the calculated ECD spectrum. All these indole-quinazoline compounds were tested for anti-bacterial and cytotoxic activities.
S2

sections.heading: 1.1 General experimental procedures
sections.text: Optical rotations were obtained with a P850 automatic polarimeter (Haineng). IR spectra were recorded with a Nicolet 6700 Fourier infrared spectrometer (Thermo Fisher). CD data were recorded with a JASCO J-810 spectrometer (JASCO). NMR spectra were recorded with a JNM-ECZ 400NB nuclear magnetic resonance spectrometer (JEOL) at 400 MHz for 1 H nuclei and 100 MHz for 13 C nuclei. Chemical shifts (δ) are given with reference to signal of solvent residue. Mass spectra were obtained using a Q Executive Focus mass spectrometer (Thermo Fisher). Semi-preparative HPLC was operated with Agilent 1260 Infinity instrument and an Ultimate XB-C18 column (10 × 250 mm, 5 μm, Welch). Column chromatography (CC) was performed using silica gel (100-200 mesh, Jiangpeng Silica Gel Company). All chemicals and solvents were of analytical or chromatographic grade.

sections.heading: 1.2 Stain material, fermentation, and isolation
sections.text:
The fungal strain SAL12 was isolated from leaves of mangrove plant Sonneratia apetala Buch.-Ham. collected in Dongzhaigang National Nature Reserve in south China’s Hainan Province. The genomic DNA of this fungus was extracted, PCR amplified and sequenced. This strain was identified as Aspergillus fumigatus by BLAST search of the 18S rRNA sequence. A voucher specimen was deposited at China General Microbiological Culture Collection Center (CGMCC) with the number of CGMCC No.40321. The Aspergillus fumigatus SAL12 strain was grown on PDA medium (20g of glucose, 20 g of agar, and 2 g of sea salt in 1 L of potato infusion). Plugs of agar supporting mycelial growth were cut and transferred aseptically to 250 mL Erlenmeyer flasks containing 100 mL of GYP medium (10 g of glucose, 10 g of yeast extract, 5 g of peptone, 2 g of sea salt in 1 L of dd H2O). The flasks were incubated at 28 °C on a rotary shaker at a speed of 120 rpm for three days as seed culture. 4.5 mL of seed culture was aseptically transferred to a 1000 mL Erlenmeyer flask containing autoclaved rice medium (80 g of rice, 0.32 g of sea salt, and 160 mL of tap water). 150 flasks were used in this work. The flasks were incubated statically at 26 °C for 35 days. The cultured
S4
medium (55 L) was extracted with equal volume of methanol three times, and then the solvent was evaporated to yield 10 L extract. The extract was partitioned with equal volume of EtOAc three times, and then samples were evaporated to give 265 g of organic extract.
The organic extract was subjected to silica gel CC using gradient elution with a petroleum ether/EtOAc mixture (100:0, 80:20, 70:30, 50:50, 30:70, 20:80, 0:100, v/v) and EtOAc/MeOH mixture (80:20, 50:50, 20:80, 0:100, v/v) to give 11 fractions (Fr.A1-Fr.A11). Fr.A8 was subjected to silica gel CC eluted with CH2Cl2/MeOH mixtures (99/1, 97:3, 95:5, 93:7, 90:10, 80:20, 0:100, v/v) to afford fractions B1–B7. Fraction B6 was purified by a semi-preparative HPLC instrument equipped with a DAD detection and monitored between 210-500 nm, using an Ultimate XB-C18 column (10 × 250 mm, 5 μm) eluted with a linear gradient from 10% CH3CN to 40% CH3CN (CH3CN-H2O system) over the course of 0–40 min at a flow rate of 2.5 mL/min to obtain compounds 1 (tR 27.3 min, 15 mg) and 3 (tR 24.1 min, 8 mg). Fraction B5 was isolated by the semi-preparative HPLC eluted with a linear gradient from 20% CH3CN to 45% CH3CN over the course of 0–30 min at a flow rate of 2.5 mL/min to obtain compound 2 (tR 29.8 min, 15 mg). Fraction B3 was purified by the semi-preparative HPLC eluted a linear gradient from 35% CH3CN to 75% CH3CN over the course of 0– 40 min at the same flow rate to give compound 4 (tR 32.1 min, 27 mg).

sections.heading: 1.3.1 Antibacterial activity assays
sections.text:
The antibacterial activities of compounds 1–4 against Staphylococcus aureus ATCC29213, Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus N315, Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus NCTC10442, Pseudomonas aeruginosa ATCC9027, and Escherichia coli ATCC 25922 were tested using a broth dilution method previously reported (Lai, et al. 2018). Briefly, the bacteria were cultivated in Mueller-Hinton (M-H) broth, and then the culture broth was transferred into a 96-well plate. The DMSO solutions of 1–4 were serially diluted by M-H broth and added into each well in the plates. The plates were placed in an incubator at 37 °C for 16 h. The absorbance was
S5
read at 630 nm using a microplate reader. Vacaomycin and amoxicillin were used as positive controls. DMSO and M-H broth were used as negative and blank controls respectively. The test was conducted in triplicate.

sections.heading: 1.3.2 Cytotoxicity assays
sections.text:
The cell growth inhibitory activities of compounds 1–4 against human cervical cancer cell lines (Hela), human breast cancer cell lines (MDA-MB-231), and human non-small cell lung cancer cell lines (A549) were determined using a MTT method previously published (Lai, et al. 2018).
Reference
Lai Z, Yu J, Ling H, Song Y, Yuan J, Ju J, Tao Y, Huang H. 2018. Grincamycins I–K, cytotoxic angucycline glycosides derived from marine-derived actinomycete Streptomyces lusitanus SCSIO LR32. Planta Med. 84(3): 201-207.

title: New glucosidated indole-quinazoline alkaloids from mangrove endophytic fungus Aspergillus fumigatus SAl12
